overall_summary: The reasoning demonstrates a systematic approach to time-series forecasting focused on identifying patterns in limited historical data (96 hourly points). It prioritizes handling seasonality and data completeness while selecting a simple, explainable method due to short history constraints. The analysis is logical but constrained by the small dataset, leading to heuristic solutions rather than complex models.
common_data_patterns: Temperature fluctuations (lower at night, higher during day)
Complete data (no missing values in provided segment)
key_insights: Reshaping data into 4x24 matrices for hourly average calculations
Explicit consideration of calendar effects (weekdays vs weekends) despite data limitations
Precision handling in output formatting to match input data specifications
Rejection of complex models due to insufficient historical data
Date-time generation logic for multi-step forecasting
complexity_analysis: Moderate complexity with strong emphasis on data preprocessing and heuristic adaptation. The reasoning involves multi-step analytical checks (seasonality detection, trend analysis, calendar considerations) but defaults to simple averaging due to data constraints, avoiding advanced statistical modeling.
